title: Does Rakan have ADHD/ADD?
body:
Whilst reading Rakan and Xayah's joint story, I couldn't help but notice that Rakan shows traits that make me believe he has ADHD or at least ADD.
As someone who has ADHD, seeing my own traits put into words with a character that I heavily relate to, it's interesting to see how other people view characters who are "spontaneous" or "uncontrollable". 

Right at the beginning of Rakan's half of the story, we can already see that his mind is racing with totally different thoughts, one leading to another in a string. 

https://i.imgur.com/TmgPLvA.png
https://i.imgur.com/zBix0hM.png

Very often, people with ADHD or ADD will notice that they've lost focus, but aren't fully capable of controlling it without practice or therapy first, a very common "mind over matter" situation.

But what strikes me the most is this paragraph.

https://i.imgur.com/i1dCzzK.png

In someone's mind, particularly when they're younger, and if they deal with ADHD, you will almost always be thinking about multiple different things with no resemblance to one another, no links at all. Your mind works very quickly with your hyperactivity because you cant stop to think about just one thing. It can be considerably difficult, because your mind is just too fast for you to keep up with. It's hard to keep track of what you do or what you need to do, and even the most simple tasks can take ages because you're busy thinking about other things. 

I think it's pretty neat if they did add such a thing to Rakan, even if it's out of game. Would be nice to see other people's opinions on it too.

EDIT: A comment from 4 Step Cadence jogged my memory! I totally forgot about voice lines.

Upon looking at Rakan's current voice lines, there are a few which specifically state that he's forgotten something.

https://i.imgur.com/kQQXKFw.png
https://i.imgur.com/NyYmvUl.png
https://i.imgur.com/Yt9hQLM.png
https://i.imgur.com/TrFZvAN.png
https://i.imgur.com/mSfzHDx.png

If you've got ADHD, you remember things a lot less than other people do. This is because your mind works too fast to store important information, and rather it will store information which is appealing to you, such as a favourite smell or taste. Rakan here shows that he is interested in the "plan" quite often, but just cant remember it.

replies.body:
No... but also yes.  (Crap, I seem to be saying that a lot recently.)

So I was the narrative design / writer for Rakan's character, VO, bio and color text.  

Creating a character's voice isn't really a science it's alchemy at best.  I can't speak for writers in general but for me it's an odd blend of, historic research, mythological research (including doing a Jungian breakdown of the archetype), psychological research; taking parts from my own--somewhat bizarre checkered--past; using my family; my friends, and sometimes TV/Film character vocal performances (strangely never games). 

I begin mix these all together in my head, and begin writing story sketches.  These short stories try and find the character's voice and often take many tries and are refined as the game kit changes.  I compared these with the archetypes the team was looking at with a variety of media figures (which display current versions of the archetype).  

At the same time, I begin monologuing --literally wandering around and trying to talk in the character's voice-- (trying different accents, tones, rhythms etc...)   Basically trying to figure out how the character thinks and what they want/need.   

Eventually, I can "do the voice".  --which I am frequently called upon to do while pitching/and performing it in riot.  Doing the voice helps gain alignment and buy-in on the VO personality.  And only after I can "do the voice" do I write the VO.  The color text-- is sometimes a modified version of the last "story sketch" i used to find the voice or a whole new short story displaying that psychological state now that I can perform it.  (then it's directing/working with an actor and other steps...)

Soooo...  that means...

Rakan contains a lot of me in my late teens early twenties, combined with several of my friends (2 women and 2 men), and a member of my extended family.  Several of the people on that list had ADD and Manic- or manic depressive behaviors.  And I did research those behaviors but only because certain people I knew were prone to that sort of thing... "and when they were drunk that one time in philly it was perfect for Rakan..."  

So creating a ADHD character wasn't a goal --it was something I arrived at backwards but then realized it was a part of him and wanted to make sure the character was psychologically accurate (i.e. A bit larger than life but still kinda realistic).  

That said-- I think part of what is important about Rakan (and makes him an unique hero) is he certainly is somewhat ADHD but he's also **extremely** emotionally intuitive, empathetic, and amazingly present.  So although Rakan find's making plans boring and focusing hard, simultaneously he is alive in the moment and hyper-aware of what everyone around him is truly feeling.

> [{quoted}](name=WAAARGHbobo,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=0009,timestamp=2018-07-13T01:34:23.408+0000)
>
>So creating a ADHD character wasn't a goal --it was something I arrived at backwards but then realized it was a part of him and wanted to make sure the character was psychologically accurate (i.e. A bit larger than life but still kinda realistic).

I'm so glad you responded! As someone who's into creative writing, seeing a character be made up like this is really interesting and new to me. It gives me a better insight on how much thought and passion goes into making characters for League, and just how much effort you put into it.

> [{quoted}](name=WAAARGHbobo,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=0009,timestamp=2018-07-13T01:34:23.408+0000)
OMG, that is beautiful.

ADHD so he can be hyper and aloof.
Depression so he can be hyper-attuned to the feelings of others.

That makes me both happy and distraught cause now I realized that he is truly depressed...which makes sense in the grand scheme of things. 

It gets to the point where your feelings are hurt, you've been wronged or maybe upset. 5 minutes later, you're perky again, and all you have is the idea or knowledge that you WERE upset, but you can't remember why. You moved on, but you're still stuck on it.

It also makes it bad that while he can comfort others' emotions, you can tell that he really can't deal with his own. Otherwise, he wouldn't have been sulking and "processing" everything in a tree with his back turned to everyone. Show and present to the world that all is okay and happy. There is no problem.  Then when i hits, make sure nobody can see. You can't afford to be a burden right now.

Stop thinking in labels. Stop saying "it makes me sad that he's depressed" if it really makes you sad, it should stand out in the character. It should come from reading his bio, his story, and hearing him speak. Its about who they are, not who they're like, and everytime you think in that way, you're thinking in caricatures not characters. 

Show don't tell, cause when you show, you produce something true to life. When you tell, you inevitably end up creating a character who is not their own entity. They become linked to some external thing, and everything they do reflects back on that thing. Inevitably, you create a situation where you attribute things in a way that is insulting, dehumanizing, and ignorant

> [{quoted}](name=Azeranth,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=000900010001,timestamp=2018-07-15T01:05:17.974+0000)
>
> Stop thinking in labels. Stop saying "it makes me sad that he's depressed" if it really makes you sad, it should stand out in the character. It should come from reading his bio, his story, and hearing him speak. Its about who they are, not who they're like, and everytime you think in that way, you're thinking in caricatures not characters. 
> 
> Show don't tell, cause when you show, you produce something true to life. When you tell, you inevitably end up creating a character who is not their own entity. They become linked to some external thing, and everything they do reflects back on that thing. Inevitably, you create a situation where you attribute things in a way that is insulting, dehumanizing, and ignorant

As someone who has those "labels" and making conjecture of understanding between the character being made and how it can play out in real life, I don't think I'm just throwing "labels."

If you want, we can discuss how modern medicine has made it to where everyone has some kind of "syndrome" or "disorder" when a few decades ago, it was just a personality trait. No illness. That's just how the person is.

Also, I'm speaking from experience as I TRULY can't hold anger for longer than 5-10 minutes cause I tend to forget what I'm angry at in the first place.

I believe your experience, but I have a very hard time picturing Rakan as depressed, even if he is inspired by some people who were.

In fact, what I especially loved about Rakan and Xayah is that they are an example of a healthy couple, secure in their relationship, and generally happy about it. Totally the opposite of all  the drama and conflicts that romantic relationships are displayed with in traditional ("Hollywood") medias, because you need a story. Here, the story wasn't about the couple, so it's just an happy couple, and it's refreshing.

And the story is about Magic and Vastayans and their hardships, but it's mostly Xayah believing in that cause, and potentially being hurt by it. Rakan mostly support Xayah herself, not her cause, and he really strikes me as a happy character.

This is what I love to see, I am glad the writers at Riot understand the difference between a character and a caricature. All to often, pandering turns to slandering as people don't understand the difference between cultural aether, and making sweepinf statements and assumptions about a the reasons a person is who they are. A+ dude, keep it up.

{{sticker:slayer-pantheon-thumbs}}

Rakan good though
I like, you did good on him
{{sticker:slayer-pantheon-thumbs}} 
Should make more like Rakan
I... Totally forgot why I'm here.

> [{quoted}](name=4 Step Cadence,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2018-07-10T15:06:07.234+0000)
>
> I... Totally forgot why I'm here.

That voice line brings up something else actually, glad you mentioned it!
I think he would as well, I head canon a lot of champions with things like this for example I am certain part of the demons Swain is dealing with includes the PTSD he brought back from the war

> [{quoted}](name=Spideraxe,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2018-07-10T14:17:35.563+0000)
>
> I think he would as well, I head canon a lot of champions with things like this for example I am certain part of the demons Swain is dealing with includes the PTSD he brought back from the war

As a Swain main since his release, I'm adopting this head canon now - the demon of secrets is a metaphor for PTSD and disillusionment.  His VO does refer to feeling "haunted," after all.
I also like to think he still has phantom pains from where his arm used to be
You know, I think you’re right.  I agree it’s cool they’re diversifying their characters in different ways like this.

> [{quoted}](name=PerchancetoGame,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2018-07-10T13:23:59.116+0000)
>
> You know, I think you’re right.  I agree it’s cool they’re diversifying their characters in different ways like this.

I'm glad someone else sees this! It's hard to find other characters like this with their stories, mostly because they're not written in first person. But hot damn it's incredible how they manage to show off a characters personality with quirks like this.

> [{quoted}](name=VARXenhal,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2018-07-10T13:31:40.844+0000)
>
> I'm glad someone else sees this! It's hard to find other characters like this with their stories, mostly because they're not written in first person. But hot damn it's incredible how they manage to show off a characters personality with quirks like this.

Right? It's additions like this that make a world and its characters come alive - as a writer, I always get a kick out of this sort of thing.

> [{quoted}](name=PerchancetoGame,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=000000000000,timestamp=2018-07-10T14:43:02.864+0000)
>
> Right? It's additions like this that make a world and its characters come alive - as a writer, I always get a kick out of this sort of thing.

Just wish there was a way we could get a confirmation out of this, if writers do actually consider stuff like mental illnesses in characters. 
I know Jinx was supposed to be "psychotic" but that itself is not a mental illness, and would be referring to psychosis.

Why do you want confirmation? What would that add to the character to have it confirmed? I hope you can take a moment and realize how incredibly dehumanizing it is to like a character due to the labels that fit on them as "mentally ill" or "LGBT" or anything else of the sort. The personality of the character should be based on what makes a good character not on some bullshit about "oh how cool would it be if they were sick in the head". 

I mean, imagine there was a character whos personality you found endearing or relatable, and suddenly, they were just a collection of labels that fit so nicely over you, and other members of the fanbase get to stroke their sympathy boners because "oh poor mentally ill character, how nice of Riot to represent these people" as if they are incapable of identifying with any other character

> [{quoted}](name=Azeranth,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=00000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-07-10T21:37:29.585+0000)
>
> Why do you want confirmation? What would that add to the character to have it confirmed? I hope you can take a moment and realize how incredibly dehumanizing it is to like a character due to the labels that fit on them as "mentally ill" or "LGBT" or anything else of the sort. The personality of the character should be based on what makes a good character not on some bullshit about "oh how cool would it be if they were sick in the head". 
> 
> I mean, imagine there was a character whos personality you found endearing or relatable, and suddenly, they were just a collection of labels that fit so nicely over you, and other members of the fanbase get to stroke their sympathy boners because "oh poor mentally ill character, how nice of Riot to represent these people" as if they are incapable of identifying with any other character

The fact that you think that having ADHD or being part of the LGBT spectrum makes you sick in the head just shows how much you missed the point of my original post. Also not to mention the fact that you put being mentally ill and being LGBT together. Don't know what point you were trying to make.

I'm saying that if someone were to confirm my theory, it would actually put me at ease to realise writers think about people individually. Not everyone is alike, and no one is perfect. People do have things wrong with them whether it's physically or mentally. 

I already liked Rakan before I thought of this theory, but piecing together his character as a whole is very enjoyable for me because it shows personality. It shows him as if he were a real person, and that's what character development is about. Characters can be incredibly relatable, and it helps us understand what the writers were trying to tell us when presenting these characters. 

Did you know that Taliyah is indirectly stated as Bisexual? Whilst I already liked her as a character before I learned that, it's a nice addition. It makes her more human. It gives people who relate to her a better understanding of her personality, her interests, her characteristics. 

I saw you also quoted another person in a different discussion about how characters are only supposed to be high quality and interesting, but that's the thing. Adding unique qualities to a character makes them interesting. It makes them different, just like us. 

Ultimately, what you've just said took my original post entirely out of context, and it was pretty rude.

> put being mentally ill and being LGBT together

There was no point being made, other than similar arguments are made about LGBT characters in other forms of media. But, seriously if you think I meant something by it, guilty conscious and all that jazz

> to realise writers think about people individually 

If you care about them individually, why do you want it confirmed they belong to a group (also realize)

To be clear, I firmly believe that a character who is well designed can exist in a vacuum, and still be interesting. Rakan would still be Rakan even if the concept of ADHD did not exist. There is nothing wrong with drawing inspiration from real people, even groups or demographics. Tahm Kench draws heavily upon southern dialects, speech pattern, dress, mannerisms. That catfish is straight from the Mississippi river.

But if I then go on to say, "Yeah we made Tahm Kench for people who are from the South" and suddenly, that's very different. Do all southerners fall into that narrow band that is Tahm Kench? Do those who don't enjoy that character type, and why the assumption they would? If it was made "for them" there is at least some level that it would be liked. You don't get gifts that people don't have ANY desire for. Are there even those who are embarrassed or ashamed that the representation of Tahm Kench is a poor explanation of their culture, and something of a strawman built on stereotypes which are dehumanizing and often insulting.

Rakan and ADHD are the same way. Do all people who have ADHD fall into that very narrow personality that Rakan is? And even if a majority of people with ADHD do, is that really the character they want as the face of their demographic? Many people consider the boundless energy, lack of memory, inability to concentrate to be crippling burden to their life. Never remembering loved ones birthdays, constantly missing details, making others feel unimportant because you weren't giving them your full attention. And how insulting is to those who do see it as a burden, yet over come this burden. The people who live with ADHD, but go on being perfectly to all outward appearance, the people who have to spend time excusing themselves to go zone-in with some privacy before getting to work. What about those who turn to drugs because they can't handle the frustration of never being able to follow through on a plan, and get their life in shape?

When a character pulls inspiration from a cultural perception of a group. When I use stereotypes and urban myths to build up a familiar character, who is charming and entertaining. There remains enough uncertainty shrouding it. It is very easy to separate the character as their own entity, and attribute them to their personal choices and situation. I can look at Rakan, and say "Yeah hes like that, but not everyone is." and not only do I know that, there is no uncertainty as to if that's the implication. If you don't understand the importance of implication, consider the following. You know that no race is inherently superior, but I imply one is. Even though I'm obviously wrong, the mere suggestion is insulting.

However, when you come out and say "This character was made with ADHD as one of the things driving their design" you've immediately started attributing all of those _Associated_ traits, as being the direct product of their supposed source. It's no longer left to the imagination, and the wisdom to know "They're not all like that, that's just this one character" goes straight out the window, because the writer has blatantly stated. "No, they're like this because of ADHD, and that is what ADHD causes. ADHD causes you to be a forgetful wreck, and we find it appropriate to mock the condition of chronic misery of absent mindedness as a legitimate illness."

At a certain point, its no longer a character, and starts becoming a **Caricature**

> [{quoted}](name=Azeranth,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=0000000000000000000000000001,timestamp=2018-07-15T00:58:40.695+0000)

original post was a headcanon
not that deep

bye
I have ADHD, and I am by definition “sick in the head”. Doesn’t mean I’m a bad person. What’s with people attacking you for dumb shit? Sorry man.

> [{quoted}](name=Xäyąh,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=0000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-07-11T05:14:12.879+0000)
>
> I have ADHD, and I am by definition “sick in the head”. Doesn’t mean I’m a bad person. What’s with people attacking you for dumb shit? Sorry man.

I wouldn't say we're sick in the head, we're just more different than others. 
As for people being ignorant, there's not much I can do. Just gotta educate others and hope they understand. :^)
My mental disorder doesn’t grant me the need for “Diversity points”
I think that if you make champions a certain way for a reason other than to be interesting and high quality, then you're degrading and dehumanizing the people that character supposedly represents

> [{quoted}](name=Azeranth,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=00000001,timestamp=2018-07-10T21:33:45.585+0000)
>
> I think that if you make champions a certain way for a reason other than to be interesting and high quality, then you're degrading and dehumanizing the people that character supposedly represents

That's just it - adding unique traits makes these characters interesting.  It's all about ways to set them apart.
I've also made correlations like this.  A lot, if not all of the Yordles, exhibit mental disorders.

> [{quoted}](name=Nanuk Pihoqahiak,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=0004,timestamp=2018-07-10T16:45:15.304+0000)
>
> I've also made correlations like this.  A lot, if not all of the Yordles, exhibit mental disorders.

I can't say much for Yordles like Poppy, Tristana, Rumble, etc.

But the ones that stick out the most to me are Kled, Gnar and Teemo. 
It's already been confirmed that Teemo has issues during his scouting, proven by his Omega Squad Skin.
Kled is pretty over exaggerated, he is delusional and has multiple hallucinations. It's obvious he's got something wrong with him but I don't wanna overstep and jump to any conclusions without knowing properly. 
Gnar is prehistoric, and he can transform when he's angry. This shows he's got anger issues, which he cant control most of the time. 

Very interesting indeed.

Veigar could be seen as a cartoony megalomaniac.

Ziggs definitely has hyperactivity going on, along with Kennen.  Although I'd argue Kennen is just more thematic given he's an embodiment of lightning.  It could also be noted that Ziggs may have Tourettes, as he randomly makes sounds while wandering around.  Moreso than any other champion, he will laugh and giggle randomly, but with a very high frequency.

Assuming Amumu is still canonically a Yordle, he's a severe case of depression.

Lulu is probably schizophrenic.

Overall, Yordles to me are one of the most interesting races, and I love the psychology that can be interpreted from their characteristics.

> [{quoted}](name=Nanuk Pihoqahiak,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=000400000000,timestamp=2018-07-11T06:41:55.901+0000)
>
> Veigar could be seen as a cartoony megalomaniac.
> 
> Ziggs definitely has hyperactivity going on, along with Kennen.  Although I'd argue Kennen is just more thematic given he's an embodiment of lightning.  It could also be noted that Ziggs may have Tourettes, as he randomly makes sounds while wandering around.  Moreso than any other champion, he will laugh and giggle randomly, but with a very high frequency.
> 
> Assuming Amumu is still canonically a Yordle, he's a severe case of depression.
> 
> Lulu is probably schizophrenic.
> 
> Overall, Yordles to me are one of the most interesting races, and I love the psychology that can be interpreted from their characteristics.

I would argue against Ziggs, personally. He laughs a lot but maybe that's because he's excited. If anything I'd say he's more of a Pyromaniac. 
I can agree with Kennen, Veigar and Lulu though!

"You're only given one spark of madness...You mustn't lose it."

Honestly one of my favorite Rakan quotes.

Can confirm

Source: I have ADD
sure why not?
As someone with ADHD, this seems pretty accurate.

> [{quoted}](name=ZackTheWaffleMan,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2018-07-10T14:14:05.023+0000)
>
> As someone with ADHD, this seems pretty accurate.

Agreed. When he first came out, my friends said he reminds them of me (I'm not as self absorbed, but the high energy giddiness is there)
Looking at your text, I think I actually have ADHD too.

> [{quoted}](name=Strigina,realm=EUNE,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kQPqEYfs,comment-id=000a,timestamp=2018-07-16T14:17:53.670+0000)
>
> Looking at your text, I think I actually have ADHD too.

If you think you've got ADHD, I really advise you seek professional help for it to diagnose you properly! 
Taking online tests and reading up symptoms that you think you might have don't guarantee that you've got something.

I think I will do, maybe I will finally find out why I can't focus on anything (unless I am reaaally interested in it) for more than few minutes no matter how hard I try.
Thanks for the advice.
